lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a video and answer comprehension questions about crazy forms of transport.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Write 3 preview Qs on the board (e.g., “What crazy vehicle do you see?”). Students answer as they watch, then discuss in pairs.
stretchStrategies: Crazy Transport Expo – After the video, groups design and draw their own “crazy transport.” They label it, explain how it works, and where it can go. Groups present in an expo-style walk-around, using unit Q&A language.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can learn about unique types of transport and compare them to transport they use.
supportStrategies: (Science) Show 3 images of transport types. Ask: “Which one is good for animals/the planet?” Discuss why in small groups.
stretchStrategies: Crazy Transport Expo – After the video, groups design and draw their own “crazy transport.” They label it, explain how it works, and where it can go. Groups present in an expo-style walk-around, using unit Q&A language.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can think creatively about what kind of crazy transport they’d like to invent and discuss how transport could be improved for the planet and animals.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Ask: “What crazy transport would you make?” Students draw and describe using 1–2 full sentences.
stretchStrategies: Crazy Transport Expo – After the video, groups design and draw their own “crazy transport.” They label it, explain how it works, and where it can go. Groups present in an expo-style walk-around, using unit Q&A language.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

Certain common places will not overlap in style or popular concept with their Western equivalents (fire station, post office, bakery, library), whereas others are more comparable (hair salon, shopping centre)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
